title: About
text:
Principal Data Scientist | Dun & Bradstreet | 2022 – Present

Building LLM-powered structured extraction pipelines for financial documents and filings
Led development of an internal geospatial library on PySpark using Uber H3 for scalable geographic indexing
Designed and deployed a multiclass text classification system for 100M+ global cargo descriptions, improving Harmonized System Code accuracy by 30+ percentage points
Led architecture of foreign influence risk analytics across 200M+ global entities, enabling custom logic via a Python/PySpark rules engine

Senior Data Scientist | Morningstar | 2020 – 2022

Built a modular portfolio backtesting library (NumPy/Pandas) for evaluating investment strategies across asset classes
Developed a two-way fixed effects model to identify crowded equity factor trades using proprietary risk factors

Data Scientist | Morningstar | 2018 – 2020

Delivered a churn prediction model using random survival forests for 100K+ retirement customers
Engineered a limit order book reconstruction tool for high-frequency trading data with millisecond-level accuracy

Associate Data Scientist | Morningstar | 2016 – 2018

Led development of a stacked ensemble propensity model, A/B tested across channels, achieving 9% uplift in adoption
Analyzed behavioral data in Neo4j to identify high-value user engagement patterns

title: Hello World: Your First Quarto Post
text: This is an example post to demonstrate Quarto blogging. Delete this post once you’ve created your own.

title: Hello World: Your First Quarto Post
text:
Quarto Basics
You can write regular markdown, include math like \(E = mc^2\), and embed code with syntax highlighting.

title: Hello World: Your First Quarto Post
text:
Code Blocks
Use triple backticks with a language name for syntax-highlighted code:

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

# Create sample data
data = {
    'Category': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'],
    'Values': np.random.randint(10, 100, 4)
}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
df








Category
Values




0
A
53


1
B
46


2
C
69


3
D
21

title: Hello World: Your First Quarto Post
text:
Executable Code
To make code actually execute and show outputs (plots, tables, etc.), add curly braces around the language name: ```{python} instead of ```python.
This requires Jupyter. Install with: pip install jupyter

title: Hello World: Your First Quarto Post
text:
Tips

Jupyter notebooks: Drop .ipynb files directly into posts/ - they render automatically
Freeze outputs: The freeze: true setting in _metadata.yml caches outputs so code doesn’t re-run on every build
Categories: Use the categories field for filtering on the blog listing page
Drafts: Set draft: true to hide posts from the listing (remove when ready to publish)

title: Brian Deignan
text:
Principal Data Scientist based in Chicago. I lead AI initiatives and build systems for messy real-world data—LLM extraction pipelines, geospatial analytics at scale, NLP for global trade. Background in econometrics (George Mason) and computer science (UIUC).
Currently at Dun & Bradstreet, previously at Morningstar.
Outside work: running, soccer, cycling, using em dashes before LLMs did.

title: CLAUDE.md
text:
This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.


Personal website for Brian Deignan built with Quarto and deployed to GitHub Pages.



# Preview site locally with live reload
quarto preview

# Build/render the site (outputs to docs/)
quarto render




Quarto website project - Configuration in _quarto.yml
Output directory: docs/ (configured for GitHub Pages)
Source files: .qmd files in root directory (index.qmd, about.qmd)
Theme: United (Bootstrap-based)
Custom styles: styles.css
Assets: Images stored in assets/
Blog: Hosted separately at https://bdeignan.github.io/blog/
